{"english":"The extent to which plant growth is adversely affected in alkaline soils"}
result.name: {"english":"alkali injury"}
{"english":"cold tolerance"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"Ability of a plant to grow and develop normally under cold conditions. Key periods of sensitivity are during seedling growth, tillering, and flowering"}

result.name: {"english":"drought recovery"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The extent to which plants recover when soaked with water after exposure to drought. The extent of recovery depends strongly on the severity of drought."}

result.name: {"english":"drought injury"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The extent to which plant growth is adversely affected by drought. Leaf rolling precedes leaf drying during drought. Response to drought is highly responsive to crop phenology, plant growth prior to stress, and the timing, duration, and intensity of drought stress. For many soils, it takes at least 2 rainless weeks during the vegetative stage to cause marked differences in response and at least 7 rainless days during the reproductive stage to cause severe drought injury. Repeated ratings are recommended through progress of the drought. Record the stage of plant growth when the stress occurred and the number of stress days."}

result.name: {"english":"stem elongation"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The ability of the stem to elongate as flood water rises and thus to keep the topmost leaves above water level"}

result.name: {"english":"heat injury"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The extent to which plant growth is adversely affected by high temperature. The key period of sensitivity is during flowering"}
{"english":"The extent to which plant growth is adversely affected by high (toxic) iron content in the growing medium"}
result.name: {"english":"iron toxicity injury"}

result.Trait description: {"english":"The ability of a stem, after it has fallen flat e.g. after floodwater recedes, to start growing upright from a young node (the knee)) and bear panicles, typically an ability expressed by deepwater varieties (applicable only in conditions where culms have fallen flat)"}
result.name: {"english":"kneeing ability"}
{"english":"phosphorus deficiency damage"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The extent to which plant growth is adversely affected by a deficiency of phosphorus in the growing medium"}
{"english":"The extent to which plant growth is adversely affected in soils or other growth medium with high salt content"}
result.name: {"english":"salt injury"}

result.Trait description: {"english":"The ability of plants to survive a period of submergence"}
result.name: {"english":"submergence tolerance"}
{"english":"zinc deficiency injury"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The extent to which plant growth is adversely affected by a deficiency of zinc in the growing medium"}

{"english":"The type and severity of bacterial blight symptoms on leaves caused by the bacterial pathogen Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae. Symptoms: lesions usually start near the leaf tip or leaf margins or both, and extend down the outer edge(s). Young lesions are pale green to grayish green, later turning yellow to gray (dead) with time. In very susceptible varieties, lesions may extend to the entire leaf length into the leaf sheath"}
result.name: {"english":"bacterial blight damage"}
{"english":"bacterial leaf streak damage"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The type and severity of bacterial leaf streak symptoms on leaves caused by the bacterial pathogen Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzicola. Symptoms: linear lesions with small bacterial exudates"}
result.Trait synonyms: {"english":"bacterial leaf streak, bacterial leaf blight, leaf blight"}

result.Trait description: {"english":"The type and severity of leaf blast symptoms on leaves caused by the fungal pathogen Magnaporthe grisea (Pyricularia oryzae). Symptoms are necrotic lesions on the leaves, in severe cases leading to leaf death"}
result.name: {"english":"Leaf blast damage"}

result.Trait description: {"english":"The type and severity of brown spot symptoms on leaves caused by the fungal pathogen Cochliobolus miyabeanus (Bipolaris oryzae, Drechslera oryzae). Symptoms: typical leaf spots are small, oval or circular and dark brown. Larger lesions usually have the same color on the edges but have a pale, usually grayish center. Most spots have a light yellow halo around the outer edge."}
result.name: {"english":"brown spot damage"}
{"english":"false smut"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The type and severity of false smut symptoms caused by Ustilaginoidea virens.  Symptoms: Infected grains are transformed into yellow-greenish or greenish-black velvety-looking spore balls."}

result.name: {"english":"grassy stunt 1 disease"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The type and severity of grassy stunt symptoms caused by the grassy stunt 1 virus (RGSV1). Symptoms: severe stunting, excessive tillering, pale green to yellow and narrow leaves with small rusty spots"}
{"english":"The type and severity of kernel smut symptoms caused by Tilletia barclayana causing kernel smut."}
result.name: {"english":"kernel smut"}

result.Trait description: {"english":"The type and severity of leaf scald symptoms on leaves caused by the fungal pathogen Monographella albescens (Microdochium oryzae). Symptoms: lesions occur mostly near leaf tips, but sometimes start at the margin of the blade and develop into large ellipsoid areas encircled by dark-brown, narrow bands accompanied by a light-brown halo"}
result.name: {"english":"leaf scald damage"}
{"english":"narrow brown leaf spot damage"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The type and severity of narrow brown leaf spot symptoms on leaves caused by the fungal pathogen Sphaerulina oryzina (Cercospora janseana)"}

result.name: {"english":"ragged stunt disease"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The type and severity of ragged stunt symptoms caused by rice ragged stunt virus (RRSV). Symptoms: plants are stunted but remain dark green. Leaves are ragged and twisted. Vein swelling on leaf collar, leaf blades and leaf sheaths"}

result.name: {"english":"rice tungro disease"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The type and severity of tungro symptoms caused by the Rice tungro virus bacilliform virus (RTBV) and rice tungro spherical virus (RTSV). Symptoms: yellow to yellow orange leaves, stunting and slightly reduced tillering"}

result.name: {"english":"sheath rot"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The type and severity of sheath rot symptoms caused by  Soracladium oryzae. Symptoms: oblong or irregular brown to grey lesions on the leaf sheath near panicle, sometimes coalescing to prevent emergence of panicle."}

{"english":"The type and severity of stem rot symptoms caused by Magnaporthe salvinii (Nakatea sigmoidea, Sclerotium oryzae) and Helminthosporium sigmoideum var. irregulare. Symptoms: dark lesions develop on the stems near the water line. Small, dark bodies (sclerotia) develop, weaken the stem and cause lodging."}
result.name: {"english":"stem rot"}
{"english":"ufra"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The type and severity of stem rot symptoms caused by the stem nematode Ditylenchus angustus. Symptoms: leaf mottling or chlorotic discoloration in a splash pattern at base of young leaves in stem elongation or mid-tillering stage, brown stains may develop on leaves and sheaths which later intensify to a dark brown color, distortion (twisting and withering) of young leaves, distortion of panicles which either remain enclosed within a swollen sheath, or partially emerge but are twisted and with unfilled grains, or emerge completely but with unfilled grains and resembling a whitehead."}

result.name: {"english":"sheath blight"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The type and severity of sheath blight symptoms caused by Thanethoporus cucumeris (Rhizoctonia solani).  Symptoms: ellipsoidal, necrotic grayish-green lesions, which may enlarge and coalesce with other lesions, initially on lower leaf sheaths"}

{"english":"The type and severity of yellow mottle disease symptoms caused by rice yellow mottle virus (RYMV). Symptoms: stunting, reduced tillering, mottling and yellowing streaking of the leaves, delayed flowering or incomplete emergence of the panicles, in extreme cases, death of plants"}
result.name: {"english":"yellow mottle disease"}
{"english":"hoja blanca disease"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The type and severity of hoja blanca disease symptoms caused by rice hoja blanca virus (RHBV) causing hoja blanca. Symptoms: cream colored to yellow spots, elongating and coalescing fo form longitudinal yellowish green to pale green striations. Streaks may coalesce to cover the whole leaf. Brown and sterile glumes with typical \"parrot beak\" shape of deformation"}

{"english":"The type and severity of udbatta disease symptoms caused by Balansia oryzae-sativae (Ephelis oryzae). Symptoms: a white mycelial mat ties the panicle branches together so that they emerge as single, small, cylindrical rods."}
result.name: {"english":"udbatta disease"}
{"english":"bakanae disease"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"In of bakanae disease symptoms caused by Gibberella fujikuroi. Symptoms: the plant elongates abnormally, has few tillers, and usually dies before producing grains"}

{"english":"The extent of damage caused by brown planthopper (Nilparvata lugens). Symptoms: Partial to pronounced yellowing and increasing severity of stunting. Extreme signs are wilting to death of plants. Infested areas in the field may be patchy"}
result.name: {"english":"brown planthopper damage"}

result.Trait description: {"english":"The extent of plant damage caused by caseworm (Nymphula depunctalis). Symptoms: only the papery upper epidermis of the leaf remains after larvae have fed on the internal leaf tissue"}
result.name: {"english":"case worm damage"}

result.Trait description: {"english":"The extent of plant damage caused by gall midge (Orseolia oryzae).  Symptoms: light-colored tubular galls resembling an onion leaf on the youngest leaf of the shoot in a tiller."}
result.name: {"english":"gall midge damage"}

result.Trait description: {"english":"The extent of damage caused by green leafhopper (Nephotettix virescens and Nephotettix cincticeps). Symptoms: partial to pronounced yellowing and increasing severity of stunting. Extreme signs are wilting to death of plants. Infested areas in the field may be patchy."}
result.name: {"english":"green leafhopper damage"}

result.Trait description: {"english":"The extent of leaf damage caused by leaffolder (Cnaphalocrosis medinalis or Marasmia patnalis). Symptoms: Larvae consume the leaf tissue except the epidermis, causing typical white streaks. They create a leaf tube during later stages of feeding"}
result.name: {"english":"leaffolder damage"}
{"english":"rice bug damage"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The extent of plant damage caused by rice bug (Leptocorisa oratorisa)."}
{"english":"The extent of plant damage caused by rice whorl maggot (Hydrellia philippina). Symptoms: maggots eat the leaf margins causing conspicuous injury and sometimes stunting of plants"}
result.name: {"english":"rice whorl maggot damage"}
{"english":"stem borer damage"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The extent of damage caused by stem borers, which include Chilo suppressalis (striped), C. polychrysus (dark headed), Rupela albinella (South American white), Scirpophaga incertulas (yellow), S innotata (white), Sesamia inferens (pink), Maliarpha separatella (African whiteheads), Diopsis macrophthalma (Stalked-eyed fly), and several other species"}
{"english":"The extent of damage caused by thrips (Stenchaetothrips biformis)"}
result.name: {"english":"thrip damage"}

result.Trait description: {"english":"The extent of damage caused by whitebacked planthopper (Sogatella furcifera). Symptoms: partial to pronounced yellowing and increasing severity of stunting. Extreme signs are wilting and death of plants. Infested areas in the field may be patchy."}
result.name: {"english":"whitebacked planthopper damage"}
{"english":"bird damage"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"The extent of damage caused by birds."}

{"english":"The extent of damage caused by rats. Symptoms: the tiller is cut at a 45 degrees angle. Damage is typically heavier in the center of a crop (stadium effect). A tiller cut through by a rodent is likely to regrow, if this is after maximum tillering then the regrown tiller is unlikely to produce panicles prior to harvest. Often the regrown, but non productive, tillers are not scored as rodent damage."}
result.name: {"english":"rat damage"}

result.Trait description: {"english":"The extent of damage caused by rice delphacid (Sogatodes oryzicola (Tagosodes orizicolus)). Symptoms: partial to pronounced yellowing and increasing severity of stunting. Extreme signs are wilting and death of plants. Infested areas in the field may be patchy."}
result.name: {"english":"rice delphacid"}

result.Trait description: {"english":"Degree of resistance to Anthracnose disease. Causative organism: Colletotrichum truncatum. Symptoms develop when plants start to flower. Necrotic lesions can be found on the lower leaflets and cause premature leaf senescence. Symptoms can also be found on stem starting from the base to the top of the plant"}
result.name: {"english":"Anthracnose resistance"}
{"english":"Aphid resistance"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"Degree of resistance to Aphids. Acrythosiphon pisum. Suck sap from tender parts of plants and it is the vector of viral diseases."}

result.name: {"english":"Ascochyta blight resistance"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"Degree of resistance to Ascochyta blight . Causative agent: Ascochyta lentis (Didymella lentis). The pathogen infects leaves, stems, petioles, pods and seeds.  On leaves, young lesions with small necrotic spots of 3-5mm diameter can be found. Reddish brown to black pycnidia from in the middle of the mature lesions.  In severe infections, lesions gridle the stem, kill the epidermal and cortical cells and lead to stem breakage. Pods can also be infected and results seed infection. Heavily infected seeds look shrivelled and discoloured with a whitish mycelium and pycnidia."}

result.Trait description: {"english":"Continuity and felicity persistence are two characteristics of the periderm of cork oak that allow the sustained exploitation of cork. However, in some cork oaks sometimes appear in the secondary phloem small peridermal arcs enveloping the sclerites or the outermost blades of the broad phloem rays, and whose new felide ends up joining the anterior path of the felogene. These sclerenchymal formations, isolated from the intercarcass by a normal process of abcision, become sclerenchymal inclusions in the suberous tissue or the felogene surface. These corks have, for these reasons, great hardness, low elasticity and high density"}
result.name: {"english":"preguentas/madeirentas'"}

result.Trait description: {"english":"A loose, pulverulent tissue with rounded cells that leave empty spaces between them, whose walls do not always overlap, filling the lenticular channels. It occurs mainly in corks with a special type of porosity in which the pores have a longitudinally conical profile. When this defect manifests itself frequently, the cork is called 'terrenta' or 'muddy', and in the most severe cases it disables the production of natural cork works."}

{"english":"Sympodial growth","french":"Ramification sympodiale"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"Assessment of sympodic growth. The apparent main axis is not developed from a terminal bud but transferred to a lateral meristem made up of successive secondary axes each of which represents one fork of a dichotomy, the other being of weaker growth or suppressed entirely.","french":"Evaluation de la croissance sympodique. L'axe principal apparent n'est pas développé à partir d'un bourgeon terminal mais transféré sur un méristème latéral constitué d'axes secondaires successifs dont chacun représente une fourche d'une dichotomie, l'autre étant de croissance plus faible ou entièrement supprimé."}

result.name: {"english":"Epicormic quantity","french":"Quantité d'épicormique"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"Assessment of epicormics quantity. These formations are appearing on trunks or master branches surfaces of living trees, resulting from buds repelled by cambial growth at the periphery on the trunk.","french":"Evaluation du nombre d'épicormiques. Ce sont des formations apparaissant à la surface des troncs ou des branches maîtresses des arbres vivants, issues de bourgeons « repoussés » par la croissance cambiale à la périphérie sur le tronc. Ces structures épicormiques regroupent principalement les bourgeons épicormiques, picots, amas, gourmands, poils et broussins (ou brognes). Ces formations sont des moyens de défense pour l'arbre."}

result.name: {"english":"Epicormic branches quantity","french":"Quantité de gourmands"}
result.Trait description: {"english":"Assessment of epicormic branches quantity, shoots growing from a dormant bud lying underneath the bark of an old structure","french":"Evaluation du nombre de gourmands, rameaux qui se développent à partir d'un oeil à bois (bourgeon dormant). Il est dit épicormique feuillé, car il pousse spontanément sur une partie exposée à la lumière d'une plante, et notamment après une phase d'auto-élagage d'un arbre lorsqu'il poussait à l'abri de la canopée ou sur un tronc émondé."}

result.name: {"english":"Epicormic branches volume","french":"Volume des gourmands"}

result.Trait description: {"english":"Assessment of primary buds quantity. The primary bud is the first to grow after the winter dormant period and is the most likely to develop a robust shoot during the growing season.","french":"Evaluation du nombre de bourgeons primaires. Le bourgeon primaire est le premier à pousser après la période de dormance hivernale et c'est le plus susceptible de développer une pousse robuste pendant la saison de croissance."}

{"english":"Assessment of secondary buds quantity. The secondary bud is present next to the primary bud within the compound bud and it is dormant until it is needed by the plant as a back up when the primary bud fails.","french":"Evaluation du nombre de bourgeons secondaires. Le bourgeon secondaire est présent à côté du bourgeon primaire à l'intérieur d'un bourgeon composé et il est dormant jusqu'à ce que la plante en ait besoin comme secours lorsque le bourgeon primaire tombe."}
